title: The NBA has a defensive three seconds problem
description: We looked at the data and found that defensive three seconds doesn’t matter when the game matters.

section.narration: We looked at the data and found that defensive three seconds doesn’t matter when the game matters.

section.text: Here’s what you need to know about defensive three seconds, basically: the floor is lava.
section.narration: Defenders can’t stand in the lane for more than three seconds -- unless they’re guarding someone. The problem is that refs miss this call all the time -- especially during the second half.

section.text: The average defensive three seconds violation is midway through the second quarter. That’s unusual.
section.narration: We expect most fouls to happen evenly throughout the game. That means the average call should occur around halftime. In reality, defensive three seconds is the only common foul that’s disproportionately called more often in the first half.

section.text: Defensive three seconds is called less often each quarter. But why?
section.narration: One explanation is that players commit fewer fouls as the game goes on because they’re more engaged, or more “locked in.” We don’t think so.

section.text: This is on the refs. Out of 141 reviewed violations at the end of close games, it was called just once.
section.narration: When called correctly, defensive three seconds has the potential to swing the balance of a game...since it results in both a free throw and possession of the ball.
So it’s understandable if referees want to enforce it with discretion. But at the same time, when it’s this blatant, it makes us wonder, if players are free to break a rule…
